   56M with asthma, DM, HTN presenting with respiratory distress and
   pneumonia/ARDS from influenza A/H1N1.
   .
   # New Respiratory failure: Originally ARDS/sepsis combined w/ fluid
   overload and possible bacterial pneumonia. Pt had a trach placed.  Has
   been off sedating drips for 2 days and had been doing well on pressure
   support.  Patient experienced distress in setting of receiving 400ml of
   IVF after being NPO for greater than 24 hours.  Vent settings adjusted
   and patient sedated.  Repeated CXR which showed pulmonary edema and
   gave lasix.  Bed in reverse Trendelenberg.  Patient improved saturation
   (100%FiO2 and 12 of PEEP to 50% and 5 PEEP) but is still agitated,
   tachypneic, and tachycardic.   Patient could have VAP especially in
   setting of recent trach placement and fever spike this morning.
   - Hold Lasix for now, pursue infectious source and restart diuresis
   possibly in the future; does not clinically appear volume overloaded
   today
   - F/u cultures of blood, sputum, and urine, f/u mini-BAL
   - Continue antibiotics: vanc, cefipime, and cipro (all 3 started on
   [**12-23**]) for MRSA and double pseudomonas coverage
   - Nebulizer treatments and suctioning
   - Sedation: d/c Fentanyl and versed. Start methadone 5mg PO q8h.
   - Attempt trach-mask trial today
   - Wean down FiO2
   .
   #Fevers/leukocytosis: Febrile to 101.4 this morning.  Pan-cultured, but
   no clear source and Cx's negative this morning.  Had been spiking
   fevers recently despite clinical improvement.  Right IJ was pulled last
   night and tip will be cultured.  Currently off of antibiotics, and
   given lack of source we will not start any medications at this time.
   Has completed courses of Azithro, Peramivir, and continuing Vanc/Aztreo
   had been discussed. However, he had  received full courses of these ABx
   and it seemed reasonable to see how he did off of these; but now, given
   fever, worsening respiratory status, and lower BP, want to start
   empiric coverage.
   - Continue antibiotics for empiric coverage = vancomycin, cefepime,
   ciprofloxacin (started all 3 on [**12-23**])
   - Follow up all cultures, including catheter tip and mini-BAL
   .
   # Tachycardia: Previously appeared to have multifocal atrial
   tachycardia. Patient started previously on Lopressor; then held for
   tenuous clinical status. Tolerating HR.
   - monitor on telemetry
   .
   # Anemia: Did have a minor surgery yesterday but wouldn't think pt
   would lose a whole unit of blood.  Repeat Hcts have been stable.  Will
   continue to follow and transfuse if below 25 so that PEG can be placed.
   - q12 hour Hct
   -transfuse if below 25
   .
   # DM2: Was on insulin gtt until recently, but now switched to Glargine
   40U qhs and SSI. Has increasing SSI needs; now on [**Month/Year (2) **]
   - Re-calculate insulin requirements today
 increase glargine to 45U
   qhs.
   .
   #PEG placement: Dobhoff placed yesterday, and is now more stable
   clinically.  Surgery and GI have deferred placement of PEG to IR b/c of
   h/o volvulus, low albumin, and low Hcts.  IR so far has agreed to do
   procedure, but will wait until clinically improves.
   - Contact IR
   - [**Name2 (NI) 1851**] with Dobhoff for now
   # Critical illness myopathy:
   - F/u PT consult
   .
   Other stable issues:
    #Renal failure: Urine output and creatinine have improved.  Has muddy
   casts on urine sediment per renal, seems to have component of ATN.  Has
   really improved with treatment and improvement of ARDS.
   - Off of lasix gtt; consider Lasix later today pending I
s and O
   - Renal team has signed off
   .
   # Eye redness and discharge: Per nursing, patient had contact in his
   right eye which was only removed the other day as there was no record
   that patient wore contacts. Unable to find contact in left eye.  Seen
   by ophthalmology who mentioned that contact was intentionally there.
   Also suggested some changes to his eye-drops and outpatient follow-up.
   Patient already has outpatient appointment set up.
   - Prednisolone and tobramycin drops to R eye as prescribed.
   - Artificial tears ointment to both eyes
   .
   # Rash: Rash seems to be improving now that zosyn d/c
d.  No signs of
   DRESS.  Has some signs of folliculitis today
   - Chlorhexadine wash on arms and legs to help prevent infection of
   follicles
   - Continue to monitor, especially w/ starting cefepime.
   .
   #Abdominal distension: Seems to have poor motility with paralysis that
   leads to increasing bowel distention.  Will continue gentle tube feeds.
   Patient has had some loose stools today, checked C. diff to ensure that
   he is not infected given that he is on a large number of antibiotics
   and was negative X3.  Rectal tube placed which seems to be improving
   his distention.
   - Bowel regimen.
   -Continue rectal tube
   .
   # Hypothyroidism: Per most recent d/c summary, Synthroid at 50mcg daily
   or 25 IV.  Continued here.
   .
   #GERD: PPI
   .
   FEN: No IVF, replete electrolytes PRN, renal tube feeds. Consider PEG
   placement soon but not today (by IR; not by GI or surgery). NG tube in
   place.
   Prophylaxis: Subcutaneous heparin; pneumoboots, PPI and bowel regimen
   Access: 2 peripherals, A-line (might need to re-wire today), IJ Central
   line pulled. Place order for PICC to be placed tomorrow, for antibiotic
   delivery.
   Code:  Full Code as discussed with parents.
   Communication: Father and mother who are in to see him daily.
   Disposition: Pending improved respiratory status.

Summary:

The patient is a 56-year-old male with a history of asthma, diabetes, and hypertension who was admitted to the ICU with respiratory failure, pneumonia, and acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS) due to influenza A/H1N1. He has been on ventilatory support and has had a tracheostomy placed. The patient has experienced fever spikes, tachycardia, and tachypnea, and has been receiving antibiotics for MRSA and pseudomonas coverage. He has also been experiencing constipation, hyperglycemia, and anemia.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP): Given the patient's recent tracheostomy placement and fever spike, there is a risk of VAP.
2. Sepsis: The patient's fever and tachycardia may indicate sepsis, which could lead to organ dysfunction.
3. Respiratory failure: The patient's ARDS and pneumonia may worsen, leading to respiratory failure.
4. Renal failure: The patient's acute kidney injury (AKI) may progress, requiring dialysis.
5. Constipation: The patient's constipation may worsen, leading to bowel obstruction or perforation.
6. Hyperglycemia: The patient's hyperglycemia may worsen, leading to diabetic ketoacidosis or hyperosmolar hyperglycemic nonketotic syndrome.
7. Anemia: The patient's anemia may worsen, requiring blood transfusions.
8. Critical illness myopathy: The patient's prolonged mechanical ventilation and critical illness may lead to critical illness myopathy.
9. Eye complications: The patient's eye redness and discharge may worsen, leading to eye infections or vision loss.
10. Abdominal complications: The patient's abdominal distension may worsen, leading to bowel obstruction or perforation.

Assessment and Plan:

1. Continue antibiotics for MRSA and pseudomonas coverage.
2. Monitor for signs of VAP and sepsis.
3. Adjust ventilator settings to improve oxygenation and reduce respiratory distress.
4. Consider diuresis to manage fluid overload and improve respiratory function.
5. Monitor for signs of renal failure and AKI.
6. Continue constipation management with bowel regimen and rectal tube.
7. Monitor for signs of hyperglycemia and adjust insulin therapy as needed.
8. Monitor for signs of anemia and transfuse as needed.
9. Monitor for signs of critical illness myopathy and adjust therapy as needed.
10. Monitor for signs of eye complications and adjust eye care as needed.
11. Monitor for signs of abdominal complications and adjust therapy as needed.

Further evaluation and management will be based on the patient's response to these interventions and the development of any new complications.

   56M with asthma, DM, HTN presenting with respiratory distress and
   pneumonia/ARDS from influenza A/H1N1.
   .
   # New Respiratory failure: Originally ARDS/sepsis combined w/ fluid
   overload and possible bacterial pneumonia. Pt had a trach placed.  Has
   been off sedating drips for 2 days and had been doing well on pressure
   support.  This morning he is tachypneic and alkalotic.  This does not
   change with decreasing pressure support.  We will tolerate this for
   now, and attempt to have more uniform sedation with long-acting
   methadone rather than bolusing fentanyl once an hour.
   - Start methadone 10mg TID
   - F/u cultures of blood, sputum, and urine, f/u mini-BAL
   - Continue antibiotics: vanc, cefipime, and cipro (all 3 started on
   [**12-23**]) for MRSA and double pseudomonas coverage
   - Nebulizer treatments and suctioning
   - Attempt trach-mask trial today
   - Wean down FiO2
   .
   #Fevers/leukocytosis: Fever curve and leukocytosis improved with
   antibiotics (on vanc, cipro and cefepime) and CV line removal. Had
   completed courses of Azithro, Peramivir, vanco and aztreonam for
   bacterial overgrowth of pneumonia.  We will continue all antibiotics
   for now and consider narrowing to single pseudomonal coverage if he
   remains afebrile.
   - Continue antibiotics for empiric coverage = vancomycin, cefepime,
   ciprofloxacin (started all 3 on [**12-23**])
   - Follow up all cultures, including catheter tip and mini-BAL
   .
   # DM2: Was on insulin gtt until recently, but now switched to Glargine
   40U qhs and SSI. Has increasing SSI needs; now on [**Month/Year (2) **]
   - Re-calculate insulin requirements today
 increase glargine to 45U
   qhs.
   .
   # Tachycardia: Previously appeared to have multifocal atrial
   tachycardia. Patient started previously on Lopressor; then held for
   tenuous clinical status. Today he is still tachycardic to the low 100s,
   but we will tolerate that for the time being.
   - monitor on telemetry
   .
   # Anemia: Hematocrits stable for several days now after trending down
   on admission.  Will continue to monitor daily.
   -transfuse if below 21
   .
   #PEG placement: Dobhoff placed yesterday, and is now more stable
   clinically.  Surgery and GI have deferred placement of PEG to IR b/c of
   h/o volvulus, low albumin, and low Hcts.  IR so far has agreed to do
   procedure, but will wait until clinically improves.
   - Contact IR
   - [**Name2 (NI) 1851**] with Dobhoff for now
   .
   # Critical illness myopathy:
   - F/u PT consult
   .
   Other stable issues:
    #Renal failure: Urine output and creatinine have improved.  Had
   component of ATN with muddy casts in urine.  Has really improved with
   treatment and improvement of ARDS.
   - Off of lasix gtt; consider Lasix later today pending I
s and O
   - Renal team has signed off
   .
   # Eye redness and discharge: Per nursing, patient had contact in his
   right eye which was only removed the other day as there was no record
   that patient wore contacts. Unable to find contact in left eye.  Seen
   by ophthalmology who mentioned that contact was intentionally there.
   Also suggested some changes to his eye-drops and outpatient follow-up.
   Patient already has outpatient appointment set up.
   - Prednisolone and tobramycin drops to R eye as prescribed.
   - Artificial tears ointment to both eyes
   .
   # Rash: Rash improved after zosyn d/c
d.  No signs of DRESS.  Did have
   some follicles which are improving.
   - Chlorhexadine wash on arms and legs to help prevent infection of
   follicles
   - Continue to monitor, especially w/ starting cefepime.
   .
   #Abdominal distension: Had poor motility with paralysis causing bowel
   distention.  Will continue gentle tube feeds. Patient has had some
   loose stools today, checked C. diff to ensure that he is not infected
   given that he is on a large number of antibiotics and was negative X3.
   Rectal tube placed which seems to be improving his distention.
   - Bowel regimen.
   - Continue rectal tube
   .
   # Hypothyroidism: Per most recent d/c summary, Synthroid at 50mcg daily
   or 25 IV.  Continued here.
   .
   #GERD: PPI
   .
   FEN: No IVF, replete electrolytes PRN, renal tube feeds. PEG to be
   placed by IR. Dobhoff in place for now.
   Prophylaxis: Subcutaneous heparin; pneumoboots, PPI and bowel regimen
   Access: 2 peripherals, A-line (might need to re-wire today). Placed
   order for PICC to be placed tomorrow, for antibiotic delivery.
   Code:  Full Code as discussed with parents.
   Communication: Father and mother who are in to see him daily.
   Disposition: Pending improved respiratory status.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 56-year-old male with a history of asthma, diabetes, and hypertension, who was admitted with respiratory failure, pneumonia, and acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS) due to influenza A/H1N1.

The patient's current condition is as follows:

* Respiratory: The patient is tachypneic and alkalotic, with a respiratory rate of 30 breaths per minute. He has a tracheostomy tube in place and is being ventilated with a CPAP/PSV mode.
* Cardiovascular: The patient has a sinus tachycardia with a heart rate of 112 beats per minute.
* Renal: The patient has acute renal failure, but his urine output and creatinine levels have improved with treatment.
* Endocrine: The patient has diabetes, and his insulin regimen has been adjusted.
* Gastrointestinal: The patient has abdominal distension, which is being managed with gentle tube feeds and a rectal tube.
* Skin: The patient has a rash, which has improved after discontinuation of Zosyn.
* Neurological: The patient has a history of critical illness myopathy, and his neurological status is being monitored.

The patient's laboratory results show:

* WBC count: 14.9 x 10^9/L
* Hemoglobin: 7.9 g/dL
* Platelet count: 955 x 10^9/L
* Creatinine: 1.1 mg/dL
* Glucose: 97 mg/dL
* Lactic acid: 1.2 mmol/L
* Albumin: 2.7 g/dL
* Calcium: 8.5 mg/dL
* Magnesium: 1.7 mg/dL
* Phosphorus: 3.1 mg/dL

The patient's imaging studies show:

* Chest X-ray: The patient's chest X-ray shows a tracheostomy tube in place, with no significant changes since the previous study.
* Mini-BAL: The patient's mini-BAL shows no organisms, with cultures pending.

The patient's plan of care includes:

* Continue antibiotics: Vancomycin, cefepime, and ciprofloxacin for MRSA and double pseudomonas coverage.
* Nebulizer treatments and suctioning.
* Attempt tracheostomy mask trial today.
* Wean down FiO2.
* Continue to monitor the patient's respiratory, cardiovascular, and renal status.
* Adjust the patient's insulin regimen as needed.
* Continue gentle tube feeds and rectal tube management.
* Monitor the patient's skin and neurological status.

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

* Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status can deteriorate further, requiring increased ventilatory support or even extracorporeal membrane oxygenation (ECMO).
* Sepsis: The patient is at risk of developing sepsis due to the presence of multiple antibiotics and the risk of bacterial superinfection.
* Renal failure: The patient's renal function can deteriorate further, requiring dialysis or other forms of renal replacement therapy.
* Critical illness myopathy: The patient's neurological status can continue to deteriorate, leading to prolonged mechanical ventilation and increased risk of mortality.
* Gastrointestinal complications: The patient's abdominal distension can lead to bowel obstruction, perforation, or other complications.
* Skin and soft tissue infections: The patient's rash can progress to skin and soft tissue infections, requiring additional antibiotic therapy.
* Hypothyroidism: The patient's hypothyroidism can worsen, requiring adjustments to his thyroid hormone replacement therapy.

   56M with asthma, DM, HTN presenting with respiratory distress and
   pneumonia/ARDS from influenza A/H1N1.
   .
   # New Respiratory failure: Originally ARDS/sepsis combined w/ fluid
   overload and possible bacterial pneumonia. Pt had a trach placed.  Has
   been off sedating drips for 2 days and had been doing well on pressure
   support.  Patient experienced distress in setting of receiving 400ml of
   IVF after being NPO for greater than 24 hours.  Vent settings adjusted
   and patient sedated.  Repeated CXR which showed pulmonary edema and
   gave lasix.  Bed in reverse Trendelenberg.  Patient improved saturation
   (100%FiO2 and 12 of PEEP to 50% and 5 PEEP) but is still agitated,
   tachypneic, and tachycardic.   Patient could have VAP especially in
   setting of recent trach placement and fever spike this morning.
   - Hold Lasix for now, pursue infectious source and restart diuresis
   possibly in the future.
   - F/u cultures of blood, sputum, and urine
   - Restart antibiotics: vanc, cefipime, and cipro for MRSA and double
   pseudomonas coverage
   - Nebulizer treatments and suctioning
   - Daily CXR
   - Sedation: bolus sedation with fentanyl and midazolam.
   - mini-BAL
   .
   #Fevers/leukocytosis: Febrile to 101.4 this morning.  Pan-cultured, but
   no clear source and Cx's negative this morning.  Had been spiking
   fevers recently despite clinical improvement.  Right IJ was pulled last
   night and tip will be cultured.  Currently off of antibiotics, and
   given lack of source we will not start any medications at this time.
   Has completed courses of Azithro, Peramivir, and continuing Vanc/Aztreo
   had been discussed. However, he had  received full courses of these ABx
   and it seemed reasonable to see how he did off of these; but now, given
   fever, worsening respiratory status, and lower BP, want to start
   empiric coverage.
   - Start antibiotics for empiric coverage = start vancomycin, cefepime,
   ciprofloxacin
   - Mini-BAL
   - Follow up all cultures, including catheter tip
   .
   # Tachycardia: Previously appeared to have multifocal atrial
   tachycardia. Patient started previously on Lopressor; yesterday held
   for tenuous clinical status.
   - restart metoprolol
   .
   # Anemia: Did have a minor surgery yesterday but wouldn't think pt
   would lose a whole unit of blood.  Repeat Hcts have been stable.  Will
   continue to follow and transfuse if below 25 so that PEG can be placed.
   - q12 hour Hct
   -transfuse if below 25
   .
   # DM2: Was on insulin gtt until recently, but now switched to Glargine
   40U qhs and SSI. Has increasing SSI needs.
   - Will calculate insulin requirements once pt has taken a full day of
   nutrition either by PEG or by TF, in order to accurately calculate
   insulin requirements. Not today, as pt currently NPO for PEG today.
   SSI.
   .
   #PEG placement: Dobhoff placed yesterday, and is now more stable
   clinically.  Should be able to
   Surgery and GI have deferred placement of PEG to IR b/c of h/o
   volvulus, low albumin, and low Hcts.  IR so far has agreed to do
   procedure, but will wait until clinically improves.
   - Reschedule gastrostomy w/ IR when improves clinically.
   # Critical illness myopathy:
   - Consult PT today
   .
   Other stable issues:
    #Renal failure: Urine output and creatinine have improved.  Has muddy
   casts on urine sediment per renal, seems to have component of ATN.  Has
   really improved with treatment and improvement of ARDS.
   - Off of lasix gtt; consider Lasix later today pending I
s and O
   - Renal team has signed off
   .
   # Eye redness and discharge: Per nursing, patient had contact in his
   right eye which was only removed the other day as there was no record
   that patient wore contacts. Unable to find contact in left eye.  Seen
   by ophthalmology who mentioned that contact was intentionally there.
   Also suggested some changes to his eye-drops and outpatient follow-up.
   Patient already has outpatient appointment set up.
   - Prednisolone and tobramycin drops to R eye as prescribed.
   - Artificial tears ointment to both eyes
   .
   # Rash: Rash seems to be improving now that zosyn d/c
d.  No signs of
   DRESS.  Has some signs of folliculitis today
   - Chlorhexadine wash on arms and legs to help prevent infection of
   follicles
   - Continue to monitor, especially w/ starting cefepime.
   .
   #Abdominal distension: Seems to have poor motility with paralysis that
   leads to increasing bowel distention.  Will continue gentle tube feeds.
   Patient has had some loose stools today, checked C. diff to ensure that
   he is not infected given that he is on a large number of antibiotics
   and was negative X3.  Rectal tube placed which seems to be improving
   his distention.
   - Bowel regimen.
   -Continue rectal tube
   .
   # Hypothyroidism: Per most recent d/c summary, Synthroid at 50mcg daily
   or 25 IV.  Continued here.
   .
   #GERD: PPI
   .
   FEN: No IVF, replete electrolytes PRN, renal tube feeds. Consider PEG
   placement soon but not today (by IR; not by GI or surgery). NG tube
   placement today.
   Prophylaxis: Subcutaneous heparin; pneumoboots, PPI and bowel regimen
   Access: 2 peripherals, A-line (might need to re-wire today), IJ Central
   line pulled.
   Code:  Full Code as discussed with parents.
   Communication: Father and mother who are in to see him daily.
   Disposition: Pending improved respiratory status.

Summary:

The patient is a 56-year-old male with a history of asthma, diabetes, and hypertension who was admitted with respiratory distress and pneumonia/ARDS due to influenza A/H1N1. He has been mechanically ventilated and has undergone tracheostomy. He has been experiencing fevers, tachycardia, and tachypnea, and has been treated with antibiotics and sedation. He has also been experiencing constipation, anemia, and hyperglycemia.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP): The patient has a tracheostomy and has been mechanically ventilated for an extended period, making him at risk for VAP.
2. Sepsis: The patient has been experiencing fevers, tachycardia, and tachypnea, which could be indicative of sepsis.
3. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status has been declining, and he may require further interventions to improve his oxygenation.
4. Acute kidney injury (AKI): The patient's creatinine levels have been elevated, and he may be at risk for AKI.
5. Constipation: The patient has been experiencing constipation, which could lead to bowel obstruction or perforation.
6. Hyperglycemia: The patient's blood glucose levels have been elevated, which could lead to complications such as diabetic ketoacidosis or hyperosmolar nonketotic syndrome.
7. Pneumonia: The patient has pneumonia, which could lead to further respiratory complications.
8. Acute lung injury (ALI): The patient has ALI, which could lead to further respiratory complications.
9. Cardiac complications: The patient's tachycardia and hypertension could lead to cardiac complications such as myocardial infarction or cardiac arrhythmias.
10. Nutritional deficiencies: The patient's prolonged hospitalization and limited oral intake could lead to nutritional deficiencies.

Assessment and Plan:

1. Continue to monitor the patient's respiratory status and adjust ventilator settings as needed.
2. Treat the patient's sepsis with antibiotics and fluids.
3. Manage the patient's constipation with bowel regimen and rectal tube.
4. Monitor the patient's blood glucose levels and adjust insulin therapy as needed.
5. Continue to provide nutritional support with tube feeds and consider PEG placement in the future.
6. Monitor the patient's electrolyte levels and adjust therapy as needed.
7. Continue to provide anticoagulation therapy with subcutaneous heparin.
8. Consider consulting with a gastroenterologist to further evaluate the patient's gastrointestinal symptoms.
9. Consider consulting with a cardiologist to further evaluate the patient's cardiac symptoms.
10. Continue to provide supportive care and monitor the patient's overall condition.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 56-year-old man with Down's syndrome who has been admitted to the ICU due to ARDS caused by Influenza PNA. The patient has a tracheostomy in place and is receiving respiratory support.

The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature curve trending down, but he is still tachypneic. His oxygen saturation is 100% on 50% FiO2. He has a respiratory rate of 21 breaths per minute and a heart rate of 94 beats per minute.

The patient's laboratory results show evidence of respiratory alkalosis, with a pH of 7.51 and a pCO2 of 29 mmHg. His creatinine level is elevated at 1.1 mg/dL, indicating acute renal failure. His glucose level is elevated at 216 mg/dL, indicating hyperglycemia.

The patient's physical examination is notable for bilateral lower extremity edema, a soft and non-tender abdomen, and warm skin. His neurological examination is limited due to his altered mental status.

The patient's diagnosis includes acute respiratory distress syndrome, pneumonia, sepsis without organ dysfunction, and acute renal failure. He is at risk for respiratory failure, pneumonia, and aspiration due to his inability to protect his airway.

The patient's plan includes continuing antibiotics for now, weaning down to a lower FiO2, and starting methadone for sedation. He will also receive increased long-acting insulin for his hyperglycemia and will have a PIC line and PEG tube placed for nutritional support.

Potential medical complications that can arise from this patient's condition include:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's ARDS and pneumonia put him at risk for respiratory failure, which could lead to the need for mechanical ventilation.
2. Pneumonia: The patient's pneumonia could worsen, leading to further respiratory compromise and potentially life-threatening complications.
3. Sepsis: The patient's sepsis could progress to septic shock, which could lead to multi-organ dysfunction and death.
4. Acute renal failure: The patient's acute renal failure could worsen, leading to the need for dialysis and potentially life-threatening complications.
5. Aspiration: The patient's inability to protect his airway puts him at risk for aspiration, which could lead to pneumonia and potentially life-threatening complications.
6. Hyperglycemia: The patient's hyperglycemia could worsen, leading to complications such as diabetic ketoacidosis and potentially life-threatening complications.
7. Constipation: The patient's constipation could worsen, leading to complications such as bowel obstruction and potentially life-threatening complications.

   The tracheostomy tip is at the midline with its tip 3 cm above the
   carina.
   The Dobbhoff tube tip is in the prepyloric location distal stomach, no
   change
   in extensive parenchymal opacities in cardiomediastinal silhouette is
   demonstrated in the short-term interval, thus the potentially present
   volume
   overload did not significantly change since the prior study.
   Microbiology: All cultures NTD; some PMN in sputum
   Assessment and Plan
   56M with asthma, DM, HTN presenting with respiratory distress and
   pneumonia/ARDS from influenza A/H1N1.
   .
   # Respiratory failure: Originally ARDS/sepsis combined w/ fluid
   overload and possible bacterial pneumonia. Pt had a trach placed.  Has
   been off sedating drips for 2 days and had been doing well on pressure
   support.  This morning he is tachypneic and alkalotic.  This does not
   change with decreasing pressure support.  We will tolerate this for
   now, and attempt to have more uniform sedation with long-acting
   methadone rather than bolusing fentanyl once an hour.
   - Start methadone 10mg TID
   - F/u cultures of blood, sputum, and urine, f/u mini-BAL
   - Continue antibiotics: vanc, cefipime, and cipro (all 3 started on
   [**12-23**]) for MRSA and double pseudomonas coverage
   - Nebulizer treatments and suctioning
   - Attempt trach-mask trial today
   - Wean down FiO2
   - 2L diuresis
   .
   #Fevers/leukocytosis: Fever curve and leukocytosis improved with
   antibiotics (on vanc, cipro and cefepime) and CV line removal. Had
   completed courses of Azithro, Peramivir, vanco and aztreonam for
   bacterial overgrowth of pneumonia.  We will continue all antibiotics
   for now and consider narrowing to single pseudomonal coverage if he
   remains afebrile.
   - Continue antibiotics for empiric coverage = vancomycin, cefepime,
   ciprofloxacin (started all 3 on [**12-23**])
   - Follow up all cultures, including catheter tip and mini-BAL
   .
   # DM2: Was on insulin gtt until recently, but now switched to Glargine
   40U qhs and SSI. Has increasing SSI needs; now on tubefeeds
   - Re-calculate insulin requirements today
 increased glargine to 45U
   qhs.
   .
   # Tachycardia: Previously appeared to have multifocal atrial
   tachycardia. Patient started previously on Lopressor; then held for
   tenuous clinical status. Today he is still tachycardic to the 80-110's,
   but we will tolerate that for the time being.
   - monitor on telemetry
   .
   # Anemia: Hematocrits stable for several days now after trending down
   on admission.  Will continue to monitor daily.
   -transfuse if below 21
   .
   #PEG placement: Dobhoff placed yesterday, and is now more stable
   clinically.  Surgery and GI have deferred placement of PEG to IR b/c of
   h/o volvulus, low albumin, and low Hcts.  IR so far has agreed to do
   procedure today.
   - Nutrition consult for PEG feeds
   .
   # Critical illness myopathy:
   - F/u PT consult
   .
   Other stable issues:
    #Renal failure: Urine output and creatinine have improved.  Had
   component of ATN with muddy casts in urine.  Has really improved with
   treatment and improvement of ARDS.
   - Off of lasix gtt; consider Lasix later today pending I
s and O
   - Renal team has signed off
   .
   # Eye redness and discharge: Per nursing, patient had contact in his
   right eye which was only removed the other day as there was no record
   that patient wore contacts. Unable to find contact in left eye.  Seen
   by ophthalmology who mentioned that contact was intentionally there.
   Also suggested some changes to his eye-drops and outpatient follow-up.
   Patient already has outpatient appointment set up.
   - Prednisolone and tobramycin drops to R eye as prescribed.
   - Artificial tears ointment to both eyes
   .
   # Rash: Rash improved after zosyn d/c
d.  No signs of DRESS.  Did have
   some follicles which are improving.
   - Chlorhexadine wash on arms and legs to help prevent infection of
   follicles
   - Continue to monitor, especially w/ starting cefepime.
   .
   #Abdominal distension: Had poor motility with paralysis causing bowel
   distention.  Will continue gentle tube feeds. Patient has had some
   loose stools today, checked C. diff to ensure that he is not infected
   given that he is on a large number of antibiotics and was negative X3.
   Rectal tube placed which seems to be improving his distention.
   - Bowel regimen.
   - Continue rectal tube
   .
   # Hypothyroidism: Per most recent d/c summary, Synthroid at 50mcg daily
   or 25 IV.  Continued here.
   .
   #GERD: PPI
   .
   FEN: No IVF, replete electrolytes PRN, renal tube feeds. PEG to be
   placed by IR. Dobhoff in place for now.
   Prophylaxis: Subcutaneous heparin; pneumoboots, PPI and bowel regimen
   Access: 1 peripherals, A-line (might need to re-wire today). Placed
   order for PICC to be placed tomorrow, for antibiotic delivery.
   Code:  Full Code as discussed with parents.
   Communication: Father and mother who are in to see him daily.
   Disposition: Pending improved respiratory status.

Based on the provided progress note, I summarize the patient's condition as follows:

The patient, a 56-year-old male, is in the ICU with ARDS, pneumonia, and sepsis, secondary to influenza A/H1N1. He has been intubated and is on mechanical ventilation with a tracheostomy in place. The patient's respiratory status has deteriorated, with increased tachypnea and alkalosis, despite decreasing pressure support.

The patient has multiple comorbidities, including diabetes mellitus, hypertension, and asthma. He has been treated with antibiotics, including vancomycin, cefepime, and ciprofloxacin, for MRSA and pseudomonas coverage. He also has a history of fluid overload, which has been managed with diuresis.

The patient's laboratory results show leukocytosis, anemia, and renal failure, which have been improving with treatment. He has also been diagnosed with critical illness myopathy, which is being managed with physical therapy.

The patient's medication list includes methadone, ativan, fentanyl, lorazepam, famotidine, and heparin, among others. He has been started on a new medication regimen, including long-acting methadone and ciprofloxacin.

Potential medical complications that can arise from the patient's condition include:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status has deteriorated, and he may require further interventions to improve oxygenation and ventilation.
2. Sepsis: The patient has sepsis, which can lead to organ dysfunction and failure if not managed promptly and effectively.
3. Renal failure: The patient has renal failure, which can worsen if not managed with diuresis and fluid management.
4. Anemia: The patient has anemia, which can worsen if not managed with transfusions and other interventions.
5. Critical illness myopathy: The patient has critical illness myopathy, which can lead to muscle weakness and paralysis if not managed with physical therapy and other interventions.
6. Hypothyroidism: The patient has hypothyroidism, which can worsen if not managed with thyroid replacement therapy.
7. GERD: The patient has GERD, which can worsen if not managed with acid suppression therapy and other interventions.
8. Abdominal distension: The patient has abdominal distension, which can worsen if not managed with bowel regimen and other interventions.

Overall, the patient requires close monitoring and management of his multiple comorbidities and complications to improve his respiratory and overall status.

Based on the provided medical note, I summarize the patient's condition as follows:

The patient is a 56-year-old male with a history of asthma, diabetes, and hypertension, who presented with respiratory distress and pneumonia/ARDS due to influenza A/H1N1. He has been admitted to the ICU and has undergone various treatments, including tracheostomy, antibiotic therapy, and mechanical ventilation.

The patient's current condition is characterized by:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient is tachypneic and alkalotic, despite decreasing pressure support. He is tolerating this condition, and the plan is to continue monitoring and adjusting his sedation as needed.
2. Fevers/leukocytosis: The patient's fever curve and leukocytosis have improved with antibiotics, and he is being continued on empiric coverage with vancomycin, cefepime, and ciprofloxacin.
3. DM2: The patient's insulin requirements are being re-calculated, and his glargine dose has been increased to 45U qhs.
4. Tachycardia: The patient's tachycardia is being monitored, and he is being continued on telemetry.
5. Anemia: The patient's hematocrits are stable, and he will be transfused if his level falls below 21.
6. PEG placement: The patient's PEG placement has been deferred due to his history of volvulus, low albumin, and low Hcts. IR has agreed to perform the procedure today.
7. Critical illness myopathy: The patient is being followed up with a PT consult.
8. Renal failure: The patient's urine output and creatinine have improved, and he is being considered for Lasix therapy.
9. Eye redness and discharge: The patient has been seen by ophthalmology, and his eye drops and outpatient follow-up have been adjusted.
10. Rash: The patient's rash has improved, and he is being monitored for signs of DRESS.
11. Abdominal distension: The patient has had some loose stools and has been placed on a bowel regimen.
12. Hypothyroidism: The patient is being continued on Synthroid at 50mcg daily or 25 IV.
13. GERD: The patient is being treated with PPI.
14. Prophylaxis: The patient is receiving subcutaneous heparin, pneumoboots, and bowel regimen.

Potential medical complications that may arise include:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's tachypnea and alkalosis may worsen, leading to respiratory failure.
2. Sepsis: The patient's ongoing antibiotic therapy and presence of bacterial pneumonia may lead to sepsis.
3. Renal failure: The patient's creatinine levels may worsen, leading to renal failure.
4. Gastrointestinal complications: The patient's abdominal distension and bowel regimen may lead to gastrointestinal complications.
5. Hypothyroidism: The patient's hypothyroidism may worsen, leading to hypothyroidism-related complications.
6. Critical illness myopathy: The patient's critical illness myopathy may worsen, leading to muscle weakness and other complications.
7. DRESS: The patient's rash may worsen, leading to DRESS syndrome.
8. PEG placement complications: The patient may experience complications during PEG placement, such as bleeding or infection.

Overall, the patient's condition is complex and requires close monitoring and management to prevent potential complications.

   Assessment and Plan
   56M with asthma, DM, HTN presenting with respiratory distress and
   pneumonia/ARDS from influenza A/H1N1.
   .
   # Respiratory failure: Originally ARDS/sepsis combined w/ fluid
   overload and possible bacterial pneumonia. Pt had a trach placed.  Has
   been off sedating drips for 2 days and had been doing well on pressure
   support.  This morning he is tachypneic and alkalotic.  This does not
   change with decreasing pressure support.  We will tolerate this for
   now, and attempt to have more uniform sedation with long-acting
   methadone rather than bolusing fentanyl once an hour.
   - Start methadone 10mg TID
   - F/u cultures of blood, sputum, and urine, f/u mini-BAL
   - Continue antibiotics: vanc, cefipime, and cipro (all 3 started on
   [**12-23**]) for MRSA and double pseudomonas coverage
   - Nebulizer treatments and suctioning
   - Attempt trach-mask trial today
   - Wean down FiO2
   .
   #Fevers/leukocytosis: Fever curve and leukocytosis improved with
   antibiotics (on vanc, cipro and cefepime) and CV line removal. Had
   completed courses of Azithro, Peramivir, vanco and aztreonam for
   bacterial overgrowth of pneumonia.  We will continue all antibiotics
   for now and consider narrowing to single pseudomonal coverage if he
   remains afebrile.
   - Continue antibiotics for empiric coverage = vancomycin, cefepime,
   ciprofloxacin (started all 3 on [**12-23**])
   - Follow up all cultures, including catheter tip and mini-BAL
   .
   # DM2: Was on insulin gtt until recently, but now switched to Glargine
   40U qhs and SSI. Has increasing SSI needs; now on tubefeeds
   - Re-calculate insulin requirements today
 increased glargine to 45U
   qhs.
   .
   # Tachycardia: Previously appeared to have multifocal atrial
   tachycardia. Patient started previously on Lopressor; then held for
   tenuous clinical status. Today he is still tachycardic to the 80-110's,
   but we will tolerate that for the time being.
   - monitor on telemetry
   .
   # Anemia: Hematocrits stable for several days now after trending down
   on admission.  Will continue to monitor daily.
   -transfuse if below 21
   .
   #PEG placement: Dobhoff placed yesterday, and is now more stable
   clinically.  Surgery and GI have deferred placement of PEG to IR b/c of
   h/o volvulus, low albumin, and low Hcts.  IR so far has agreed to do
   procedure today.
   - Contact IR for scheduling
   - Nutrition consult for PEG feeds
   .
   # Critical illness myopathy:
   - F/u PT consult
   .
   Other stable issues:
    #Renal failure: Urine output and creatinine have improved.  Had
   component of ATN with muddy casts in urine.  Has really improved with
   treatment and improvement of ARDS.
   - Off of lasix gtt; consider Lasix later today pending I
s and O
   - Renal team has signed off
   .
   # Eye redness and discharge: Per nursing, patient had contact in his
   right eye which was only removed the other day as there was no record
   that patient wore contacts. Unable to find contact in left eye.  Seen
   by ophthalmology who mentioned that contact was intentionally there.
   Also suggested some changes to his eye-drops and outpatient follow-up.
   Patient already has outpatient appointment set up.
   - Prednisolone and tobramycin drops to R eye as prescribed.
   - Artificial tears ointment to both eyes
   .
   # Rash: Rash improved after zosyn d/c
d.  No signs of DRESS.  Did have
   some follicles which are improving.
   - Chlorhexadine wash on arms and legs to help prevent infection of
   follicles
   - Continue to monitor, especially w/ starting cefepime.
   .
   #Abdominal distension: Had poor motility with paralysis causing bowel
   distention.  Will continue gentle tube feeds. Patient has had some
   loose stools today, checked C. diff to ensure that he is not infected
   given that he is on a large number of antibiotics and was negative X3.
   Rectal tube placed which seems to be improving his distention.
   - Bowel regimen.
   - Continue rectal tube
   .
   # Hypothyroidism: Per most recent d/c summary, Synthroid at 50mcg daily
   or 25 IV.  Continued here.
   .
   #GERD: PPI
   .
   FEN: No IVF, replete electrolytes PRN, renal tube feeds. PEG to be
   placed by IR. Dobhoff in place for now.
   Prophylaxis: Subcutaneous heparin; pneumoboots, PPI and bowel regimen
   Access: 2 peripherals, A-line (might need to re-wire today). Placed
   order for PICC to be placed tomorrow, for antibiotic delivery.
   Code:  Full Code as discussed with parents.
   Communication: Father and mother who are in to see him daily.
   Disposition: Pending improved respiratory status.
   ICU Care
   Nutrition:
   Glycemic Control:

Based on the patient's daily progress note, I summarize the information as follows:

The patient is a 56-year-old male with asthma, diabetes, and hypertension who presented with respiratory distress and pneumonia/ARDS due to influenza A/H1N1. He has been admitted to the ICU for 3 days and has been receiving mechanical ventilation.

The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 37.4°C, heart rate of 90 beats per minute, and blood pressure of 117/64 mmHg. His respiratory rate is 16 breaths per minute, and his oxygen saturation is 97% on 50% FiO2.

The patient's laboratory results show an increase in white blood cell count, with a peak of 14.9 x 10^9/L, and a decrease in hemoglobin, with a level of 7.4 g/dL. His creatinine level is 1.1 mg/dL, and his blood urea nitrogen (BUN) level is 24 mg/dL.

The patient's imaging studies show no change in the extent of parenchymal opacities in the cardiomediastinal silhouette, suggesting that the potentially present volume overload did not significantly change since the prior study.

The patient's medical plan includes the continuation of antibiotics, including vancomycin, cefepime, and ciprofloxacin, for MRSA and double pseudomonas coverage. He is also receiving nebulizer treatments and suctioning, and an attempt will be made to wean down his FiO2.

Potential medical complications that can arise from the patient's condition include:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory rate is increasing, and his oxygen saturation is decreasing, which may indicate worsening respiratory failure.
2. Sepsis: The patient's white blood cell count is increasing, and his temperature is fluctuating, which may indicate the development of sepsis.
3. Acute kidney injury: The patient's creatinine level is increasing, and his BUN level is decreasing, which may indicate acute kidney injury.
4. Gastrointestinal complications: The patient has been experiencing abdominal distension, which may be due to poor motility or bowel obstruction.
5. Eye complications: The patient has been experiencing eye redness and discharge, which may be due to infection or irritation.
6. Skin rash: The patient has been experiencing a rash, which may be due to an allergic reaction or infection.
7. Critical illness myopathy: The patient's muscle weakness may be due to critical illness myopathy, which is a common complication of critical illness.

Based on the patient's condition, it is essential to monitor his vital signs closely and adjust his treatment plan accordingly. The patient's respiratory status should be closely monitored, and the dosage of his antibiotics should be adjusted based on the results of his blood cultures. The patient's gastrointestinal status should also be monitored, and his abdominal distension should be managed with gentle tube feeds and rectal tube placement. The patient's eye and skin complications should be managed with topical antibiotics and antihistamines, respectively.

 PULMONARY EDEMA
 FEVER (HYPERTHERMIA, PYREXIA, NOT FEVER OF UNKNOWN ORIGIN)
 TACHYCARDIA, OTHER
 RASH
 RENAL FAILURE, ACUTE (ACUTE RENAL FAILURE, ARF)
 CONSTIPATION (OBSTIPATION, FOS)

 ACUTE RESPIRATORY DISTRESS SYNDROME (ARDS, ACUTE LUNG INJURY, [**Doctor Last Name 76**])

 PNEUMONIA, OTHER
 AIRWAY, INABILITY TO PROTECT (RISK FOR ASPIRATION, ALTERED GAG,
   AIRWAY CLEARANCE, COUGH)
   56M with asthma, DM, HTN presenting with respiratory distress and
   pneumonia/ARDS from influenza A/H1N1.
   # Respiratory failure: Originally ARDS/sepsis combined w/ fluid
   overload and possible bacterial pneumonia. Pt had a trach placed.  Has
   been off sedating drips for 3 days and had been doing well on pressure
   support.  This morning he continues to be respiratorily alkalotic. Has
   started on Methadone to try and decrease his tachypnea, instead of
   bolusing sedatives.
   - Continue methadone 10mg TID to address tachypnea
   - F/u ABG this afternoon
   - Trach mask trial later today
   - F/u cultures of blood, sputum, and urine, f/u mini-BAL
   - Continue antibiotics: vanc, cefipime, and cipro (all 3 started on
   [**12-23**] --> today is day 4) for MRSA and double pseudomonas coverage
   - Nebulizer treatments and suctioning
   - Wean down FiO2
   - 2L diuresis again today given worsening effusions
   #Fevers/leukocytosis: Fever curve and leukocytosis improved with
   antibiotics (on vanc, cipro and cefepime) and CV line removal. Had
   completed courses of Azithro, Peramivir, vanco and aztreonam for
   bacterial overgrowth of pneumonia.  We will continue all antibiotics
   for now and consider narrowing to single pseudomonal coverage if he
   remains afebrile.
   - Continue antibiotics for empiric coverage = vancomycin, cefepime,
   ciprofloxacin (started all 3 on [**12-23**])
   - Follow up all cultures, including catheter tip and mini-BAL
   # DM2: Was on insulin gtt until recently, but now switched to Glargine
   40U qhs and SSI. Has increasing SSI needs; now on tubefeeds
   - Re-calculate insulin requirements today
 increased glargine to 45U
   qhs.
   - Watch BS's through the day and increase accordingly
   # Tachycardia: Previously appeared to have multifocal atrial
   tachycardia. Patient started previously on Lopressor; then held for
   tenuous clinical status. Today he is still tachycardic to the 80-110's,
   but we will tolerate that for the time being.
   - monitor on telemetry
   # Anemia: Hematocrits stable for several days now after trending down
   on admission.  Will continue to monitor daily.
   -transfuse if below 21
   #PEG placement: Currently getting Novasource renal
   # Critical illness myopathy:
   - F/u PT consult
   Other stable issues:
    #Renal failure: Urine output and creatinine have improved.  Had
   component of ATN with muddy casts in urine.  Has really improved with
   treatment and improvement of ARDS.
   - Off of lasix gtt; consider Lasix later today pending I
s and O
   - Renal team has signed off
   # Eye redness and discharge: Per nursing, patient had contact in his
   right eye which was only removed the other day as there was no record
   that patient wore contacts. Unable to find contact in left eye.  Seen
   by ophthalmology who mentioned that contact was intentionally there.
   Also suggested some changes to his eye-drops and outpatient follow-up.
   Patient already has outpatient appointment set up.
   - Prednisolone and tobramycin drops to R eye as prescribed.
   - Artificial tears ointment to both eyes
   # Rash: Rash improved after zosyn d/c
d.  No signs of DRESS.  Did have
   some follicles which are improving.
   - Chlorhexadine wash on arms and legs to help prevent infection of
   follicles
   - Continue to monitor, especially w/ starting cefepime.
   #Abdominal distension: Had poor motility with paralysis causing bowel
   distention.  Will continue gentle tube feeds. Patient has had some
   loose stools today, checked C. diff to ensure that he is not infected
   given that he is on a large number of antibiotics and was negative X3.
   Rectal tube placed which seems to be improving his distention.
   - Bowel regimen.
   - Continue rectal tube
   # Hypothyroidism: Per most recent d/c summary, Synthroid at 50mcg daily
   or 25 IV.  Continued here.
   #GERD: PPI
   FEN: No IVF, replete electrolytes PRN, renal tube feeds.
   Prophylaxis: Subcutaneous heparin; pneumoboots, PPI and bowel regimen
   Access: 1 peripherals, A-line (might need to re-wire today). Placed
   order for PICC to be placed tomorrow, for antibiotic delivery.
   Code:  Full Code as discussed with parents.
   Communication: Father and mother who are in to see him daily.
   Disposition: Pending improved respiratory status.
   ICU Care
   Nutrition:
   Glycemic Control:
   Lines:
   Arterial Line - [**2111-12-18**] 08:22 PM
   20 Gauge - [**2111-12-22**] 12:00 PM
   Prophylaxis:
   DVT:
   Stress ulcer:
   VAP:
   Comments:
   Communication:  Comments:
   Code status:
   Disposition:

Summary:

The patient is a 56-year-old male with a history of asthma, diabetes, and hypertension, who presented with respiratory distress and pneumonia/ARDS due to influenza A/H1N1. He has been in the ICU for several days and has undergone various interventions, including tracheostomy placement, antibiotic therapy, and mechanical ventilation. He remains critically ill, with ongoing respiratory alkalosis, tachypnea, and hypoxia. He has also developed several complications, including renal failure, constipation, hyperglycemia, and a rash.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's ongoing respiratory alkalosis and tachypnea may indicate a risk of further respiratory deterioration, including respiratory failure.
2. Sepsis: The patient's persistent fever and leukocytosis may indicate ongoing sepsis, which could lead to organ dysfunction and failure.
3. Renal failure: The patient's ongoing renal failure may worsen if not managed appropriately, leading to further electrolyte imbalances and acid-base disturbances.
4. Constipation: The patient's constipation may worsen if not managed with adequate bowel care, leading to further complications such as bowel obstruction or perforation.
5. Hyperglycemia: The patient's hyperglycemia may worsen if not managed with insulin therapy, leading to further complications such as diabetic ketoacidosis or hyperosmolar hyperglycemic nonketotic syndrome.
6. Rash: The patient's rash may worsen if not managed with appropriate antibiotics and wound care, leading to further complications such as cellulitis or sepsis.
7. Pneumonia: The patient's ongoing pneumonia may worsen if not managed with appropriate antibiotics and respiratory support, leading to further complications such as respiratory failure or sepsis.
8. Acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS): The patient's ongoing ARDS may worsen if not managed with appropriate mechanical ventilation and respiratory support, leading to further complications such as respiratory failure or multiorgan dysfunction.
9. Sepsis-induced cardiomyopathy: The patient's ongoing sepsis may lead to cardiomyopathy, which could worsen his cardiovascular function and increase his risk of cardiovascular complications.
10. Prolonged mechanical ventilation: The patient's prolonged mechanical ventilation may increase his risk of ventilator-associated complications, such as ventilator-associated pneumonia or lung injury.

Recommendations:

1. Continue to monitor the patient's respiratory status closely and adjust his mechanical ventilation settings as needed to maintain optimal oxygenation and ventilation.
2. Continue to manage the patient's sepsis with antibiotics and fluids, and consider adding additional antibiotics if his infection is not improving.
3. Continue to manage the patient's renal failure with diuretics and fluids, and consider adding additional medications if his kidney function is not improving.
4. Continue to manage the patient's constipation with laxatives and bowel care, and consider adding additional medications if his bowel function is not improving.
5. Continue to manage the patient's hyperglycemia with insulin therapy, and consider adjusting his insulin regimen as needed to maintain optimal glucose control.
6. Continue to manage the patient's rash with antibiotics and wound care, and consider adding additional medications if his rash is not improving.
7. Consider adding additional antibiotics or antiviral medications if the patient's pneumonia or ARDS is not improving.
8. Consider adding additional cardiovascular medications if the patient's sepsis-induced cardiomyopathy is not improving.
9. Consider weaning the patient from mechanical ventilation if his respiratory status improves and he is able to breathe independently.
10. Consider transferring the patient to a step-down unit or a regular hospital floor if his condition improves and he no longer requires ICU-level care.

   56M with asthma, DM, HTN presenting with respiratory distress and
   pneumonia/ARDS from influenza A/H1N1.
   # Respiratory failure: Originally ARDS/sepsis combined w/ fluid
   overload and possible bacterial pneumonia. Pt had a trach placed.  Has
   been off sedating drips for several days and had been doing well on
   pressure support.  Has started on Methadone to try and decrease his
   tachypnea, instead of bolusing sedatives, and also as a wean from the
   sedation that he has been on for the past several weeks.
   - Continue methadone 10mg TID to address tachypnea
   - F/u ABG this afternoon
   - Trach mask trial later today
   - F/u cultures of blood, sputum, and urine, f/u mini-BAL
   - Will d/c ABx today as we have no clear source that we were treating
   - Nebulizer treatments and suctioning
   - Wean down FiO2
   #Fevers/leukocytosis: Fever curve and leukocytosis improved with
   antibiotics (on vanc, cipro and cefepime) and CV line removal. Had
   completed courses of Azithro, Peramivir, vanco and aztreonam for
   bacterial overgrowth of pneumonia, was then restarted on
   Vanc/Cefepime/Cipro.
   - Will d/c ABx as above as we have no clear source that we are
   treating.
   - Follow up all cultures, including catheter tip and mini-BAL
   # DM2: Was on insulin gtt until recently, but now switched to Glargine
   40U qhs and SSI. Has increasing SSI needs; now on tubefeeds
   - Glargine has been recently increased to 45 qhs
   - Watch BS's through the day and increase accordingly
   # Tachycardia: Previously appeared to have multifocal atrial
   tachycardia. Patient started previously on Lopressor; then held for
   tenuous clinical status.
   - monitor on telemetry
   # Anemia: Hematocrits stable for several days now after trending down
   on admission.  Will continue to monitor daily.
   -transfuse if below 21
   #PEG placement: Currently getting Novasource renal
   # Critical illness myopathy:
   - F/u PT consult
   Other stable issues:
    #Renal failure: Urine output and creatinine have improved.  Had
   component of ATN with muddy casts in urine.  Has really improved with
   treatment and improvement of ARDS.
   - Renal team has signed off
   - Cr within baseline
   # Eye redness and discharge: Per nursing, patient had contact in his
   right eye which was only removed the other day as there was no record
   that patient wore contacts. Unable to find contact in left eye.  Seen
   by ophthalmology who mentioned that contact was intentionally there.
   Also suggested some changes to his eye-drops and outpatient follow-up.
   Patient already has outpatient appointment set up.
   - Prednisolone and tobramycin drops to R eye as prescribed.
   - Artificial tears ointment to both eyes
   # Rash: Rash improved after zosyn d/c
d.  No signs of DRESS.  Did have
   some follicles which are improving.
   - Chlorhexadine wash on arms and legs to help prevent infection of
   follicles
   # Hypothyroidism: Per most recent d/c summary, Synthroid at 50mcg daily
   or 25 IV.  Continued here.
   #GERD: PPI
   FEN: No IVF, replete electrolytes PRN, renal tube feeds.
   Prophylaxis: Subcutaneous heparin; pneumoboots, PPI and bowel regimen
   Access: 1 peripherals, A-line. Placed order for PICC to be placed
   tomorrow, for antibiotic delivery.
   Code:  Full Code as discussed with parents.

1. Respiratory failure: The patient has a history of ARDS and pneumonia, and is currently on ventilatory support. There is a risk of further respiratory deterioration, particularly with the worsening effusions on CXR.
2. Sepsis: The patient has been on antibiotics for several days, but has not shown significant improvement. There is a risk of ongoing sepsis, particularly with the presence of leukocytosis and fever.
3. Renal failure: The patient has a history of acute renal failure, and there is a risk of ongoing renal damage, particularly with the presence of muddy casts in the urine.
4. Constipation: The patient is on tubefeeds and has a history of constipation. There is a risk of worsening constipation, particularly with the use of opioids such as methadone.
5. Hyperglycemia: The patient has a history of diabetes and is on insulin therapy. There is a risk of worsening hyperglycemia, particularly with the use of steroids and other medications.
6. Pneumonia: The patient has a history of pneumonia, and there is a risk of further respiratory deterioration, particularly with the worsening effusions on CXR.
7. Airway compromise: The patient has a tracheostomy tube in place, and there is a risk of airway compromise, particularly with the use of sedatives and other medications.
8. Hypothyroidism: The patient has a history of hypothyroidism, and there is a risk of worsening hypothyroidism, particularly with the use of steroids and other medications.
9. GERD: The patient has a history of GERD, and there is a risk of worsening GERD, particularly with the use of PPIs and other medications.
10. DVT: The patient is at risk of developing DVT, particularly with the use of central venous catheters and other medical devices.

* Methadone 10mg TID for tachypnea

The patient's current medications and labs suggest that he is at risk for several medical complications, including respiratory failure, sepsis, renal failure, constipation, hyperglycemia, pneumonia, airway compromise, hypothyroidism, GERD, and DVT.

Based on the patient's progress note, here is a summary of the patient's condition and potential medical complications:

**Current Condition:**

* The patient is a mechanically ventilated, intubated patient with acute respiratory failure and pneumonia.
* The patient's oxygenation is adequate, with SpO2 of 100%.
* The patient's respiratory support includes a tracheostomy tube and non-invasive positive pressure ventilation (NIPPV) with a fraction of inspired oxygen (FiO2) of 50%.
* The patient's hemodynamic monitoring shows a heart rate of 89 beats per minute, blood pressure of 112/64 mmHg, and a respiratory rate of 13 breaths per minute.
* The patient's laboratory results show anemia with a hemoglobin level of 7.7 g/dL, and elevated white blood cell count with a WBC of 10.1 x 10^9/L.

**Potential Medical Complications:**

* Respiratory failure: The patient's acute respiratory failure may worsen, leading to further decline in lung function and potentially life-threatening complications such as respiratory arrest.
* Pneumonia: The patient's pneumonia may progress, leading to further respiratory failure, sepsis, and potentially life-threatening complications.
* Sepsis: The patient's sepsis may worsen, leading to multi-organ dysfunction and potentially life-threatening complications.
* Renal failure: The patient's acute renal failure may worsen, leading to further decline in kidney function and potentially life-threatening complications.
* Hyperglycemia: The patient's hyperglycemia may worsen, leading to further complications such as diabetic ketoacidosis and potentially life-threatening complications.
* Constipation: The patient's constipation may worsen, leading to further complications such as bowel obstruction and potentially life-threatening complications.
* Airway compromise: The patient's airway compromise may worsen, leading to further respiratory failure and potentially life-threatening complications.

**Assessment and Plan:**

* The patient's alkalosis, respiratory failure, and pulmonary edema require ongoing respiratory support and close monitoring.
* The patient's fever, tachycardia, and rash require further evaluation and treatment.
* The patient's renal failure, hyperglycemia, and constipation require ongoing management and close monitoring.
* The patient's airway compromise requires ongoing monitoring and management to prevent further respiratory failure.

**Recommendations:**

* Continue to closely monitor the patient's respiratory status and adjust ventilation settings as necessary.
* Continue to evaluate and treat the patient's fever, tachycardia, and rash.
* Continue to manage the patient's renal failure, hyperglycemia, and constipation.
* Consider stopping antibiotics with no definitive infection identified.
* Continue to monitor the patient's airway status and adjust management as necessary.

   56M with asthma, DM, HTN presenting with respiratory distress and
   pneumonia/ARDS from influenza A/H1N1.
   # Respiratory failure:  Now on trach collar and tolerating well.
   Mildly tachypneic when interacting with people, but otherwise has RR
   down to 12-13.  Will start to wean methadone.  Now off of antibiotics
   and afebrile.  Still requiring frequent suctioning of thick secretions,
   but has a good cough.
   - wean methadone to 7.5mg TID
   - Nebulizer treatments and suctioning
   - Wean down FiO2
   #Fevers/leukocytosis: Fever curve and leukocytosis improved with
   antibiotics (on vanc, cipro and cefepime) and CV line removal. Had
   completed courses of Azithro, Peramivir, vanco and aztreonam for
   bacterial overgrowth of pneumonia, was then restarted on
   Vanc/Cefepime/Cipro, which was stopped yesterday b/c there was no clear
   source for his recent fevers.
   - follow-up remaining pending cultures.
   # DM2: Mildly hypoglycemic overnight, now stable.  Recently restarted
   tubefeeds, which are now at goal.
   Glargine reduced to 35units QHS.
   - Watch BS's through the day tomorrow.
   # Tachycardia: Previously appeared to have multifocal atrial
   tachycardia. Patient started previously on Lopressor; then held for
   tenuous clinical status.
   - monitor on telemetry
   # Anemia: Hematocrits stable for several days now after trending down
   on admission.  Will continue to monitor daily.
   -transfuse if below 21
   # Thrombocytosis: patient has had stably high platelet counts, which is
   new on this admission and likely reactive.
   - monitor daily.
   #PEG placement: Currently getting Novasource renal
   # Critical illness myopathy:
   - F/u PT consult
    #Renal failure: Urine output and creatinine have improved.  Had
   component of ATN with muddy casts in urine.  Has really improved with
   treatment and improvement of ARDS.
   - Renal team has signed off
   - Cr within baseline
   # Eye redness and discharge: Per nursing, patient had contact in his
   right eye which was only removed the other day as there was no record
   that patient wore contacts. Unable to find contact in left eye.  Seen
   by ophthalmology who mentioned that contact was intentionally there.
   Patient already has outpatient appointment set up.
   - Prednisolone and tobramycin drops to R eye as prescribed.
   - Artificial tears ointment to both eyes
   # Rash: Rash improved after zosyn d/c
d.  No signs of DRESS.  Did have
   some follicles which are improving.
   - Chlorhexadine wash on arms and legs to help prevent infection of
   follicles
   # Hypothyroidism: Per most recent d/c summary, Synthroid at 50mcg daily
   or 25 IV.  Continued here.
   #GERD: PPI
   FEN: No IVF, replete electrolytes PRN, renal tube feeds.
   Prophylaxis: Subcutaneous heparin; pneumoboots, PPI and bowel regimen
   Access: 1 peripheral, A-line. Mid-line (was supposed to be PICC, but
   would not advance fully).
   Code:  Full Code as discussed with parents.
   Communication: Father and mother who are in to see him daily.
   Disposition: Pending improved respiratory status.

   56M with asthma, DM, HTN presenting with respiratory distress and
   pneumonia/ARDS from influenza A/H1N1.
   # Respiratory failure:  Now on trach collar and tolerating well.
   Mildly tachypneic when interacting with people, but otherwise has RR
   down to 12-13.  Will start to wean methadone.  Now off of antibiotics
   and afebrile.  Still requiring frequent suctioning of thick secretions,
   but has a good cough.
   - wean methadone to 7.5mg TID
   - Nebulizer treatments and suctioning
   - Wean down FiO2
   #Fevers/leukocytosis: Fever curve and leukocytosis improved with
   antibiotics (on vanc, cipro and cefepime) and CV line removal. Had
   completed courses of Azithro, Peramivir, vanco and aztreonam for
   bacterial overgrowth of pneumonia, was then restarted on
   Vanc/Cefepime/Cipro, which was stopped yesterday b/c there was no clear
   source for his recent fevers.
   - follow-up remaining pending cultures.
   # DM2: Mildly hypoglycemic overnight, now stable.  Recently restarted
   tubefeeds, which are now at goal.
   Glargine reduced to 35units QHS.
   - Watch BS's through the day tomorrow.
   # Tachycardia: Previously appeared to have multifocal atrial
   tachycardia. Patient started previously on Lopressor; then held for
   tenuous clinical status.
   - monitor on telemetry
   # Anemia: Hematocrits stable for several days now after trending down
   on admission.  Will continue to monitor daily.
   -transfuse if below 21
   # Thrombocytosis: patient has had stably high platelet counts, which is
   new on this admission and likely reactive.
   - monitor daily.
   #PEG placement: Currently getting Novasource renal
   # Critical illness myopathy:
   - F/u PT consult
    #Renal failure: Urine output and creatinine have improved.  Had
   component of ATN with muddy casts in urine.  Has really improved with
   treatment and improvement of ARDS.
   - Renal team has signed off
   - Cr within baseline
   # Eye redness and discharge: Per nursing, patient had contact in his
   right eye which was only removed the other day as there was no record
   that patient wore contacts. Unable to find contact in left eye.  Seen
   by ophthalmology who mentioned that contact was intentionally there.
   Patient already has outpatient appointment set up.
   - Prednisolone and tobramycin drops to R eye as prescribed.
   - Artificial tears ointment to both eyes
   # Rash: Rash improved after zosyn d/c
d.  No signs of DRESS.  Did have
   some follicles which are improving.
   - Chlorhexadine wash on arms and legs to help prevent infection of
   follicles
   # Hypothyroidism: Per most recent d/c summary, Synthroid at 50mcg daily
   or 25 IV.  Continued here.
   #GERD: PPI
   FEN: No IVF, replete electrolytes PRN, renal tube feeds.
   Prophylaxis: Subcutaneous heparin; pneumoboots, PPI and bowel regimen
   Access: 1 peripheral, A-line. Mid-line (was supposed to be PICC, but
   would not advance fully).
   Code:  Full Code as discussed with parents.
   Communication: Father and mother who are in to see him daily.
   Disposition: Pending improved respiratory status.<|eot_id|><|start_header_id|>assistant<|end_header_id|>

Based on the progress note, the patient is a 56-year-old male with a history of asthma, diabetes mellitus (DM), and hypertension, who presented with respiratory distress and pneumonia/ARDS due to influenza A/H1N1. He is currently recovering in the ICU.

The patient's current condition is as follows:

* Respiratory: He is on tracheostomy collar and tolerating well. His respiratory rate (RR) is down to 12-13, and he is mildly tachypneic when interacting with people. He requires frequent suctioning of thick secretions, but has a good cough.
* Fevers/Leukocytosis: His fever curve and leukocytosis have improved with antibiotics and CV line removal.
* DM2: He is mildly hypoglycemic overnight, but now stable. He is receiving tubefeeds, which are at goal, and his insulin dose has been reduced to 35 units QHS.
* Tachycardia: He has multifocal atrial tachycardia, and his heart rate is monitored on telemetry.
* Anemia: His hematocrits are stable, and he will be transfused if his hematocrit falls below 21.
* Thrombocytosis: His platelet counts are stably high, which is likely reactive.
* PEG placement: He is receiving Novasource renal tube feeds.
* Critical illness myopathy: He is being followed by a physical therapy consult.
* Renal failure: His urine output and creatinine have improved, and he has been weaned off renal replacement therapy.
* Eye redness and discharge: He has eye redness and discharge, which is being treated with prednisolone and tobramycin drops, as well as artificial tears ointment.
* Rash: His rash has improved, and he is being treated with chlorhexadine wash to prevent infection of follicles.
* Hypothyroidism: He is receiving Synthroid 50mcg daily or 25 IV.
* GERD: He is receiving PPI.

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

* Respiratory failure: He is at risk of respiratory failure due to his underlying ARDS and pneumonia.
* Sepsis: He is at risk of sepsis due to his underlying pneumonia and possible bacteremia.
* Renal failure: He is at risk of renal failure due to his underlying ARDS and pneumonia.
* Hypoglycemia: He is at risk of hypoglycemia due to his underlying DM and the potential for insulin therapy to be disrupted.
* Tachycardia: He is at risk of tachycardia due to his underlying multifocal atrial tachycardia.
* Anemia: He is at risk of anemia due to his underlying ARDS and pneumonia.
* Thrombocytosis: He is at risk of thrombocytosis due to his underlying ARDS and pneumonia.
* PEG placement: He is at risk of complications related to PEG placement, such as bleeding, infection, and bowel obstruction.
* Critical illness myopathy: He is at risk of critical illness myopathy due to his underlying ARDS and pneumonia.
* Eye redness and discharge: He is at risk of complications related to eye redness and discharge, such as infection and vision loss.
* Rash: He is at risk of complications related to his rash, such as infection and skin breakdown.
* Hypothyroidism: He is at risk of complications related to hypothyroidism, such as fatigue, weight gain, and cold intolerance.
* GERD: He is at risk of complications related to GERD, such as aspiration, pneumonia, and esophageal stricture.

   completed courses of Azithro, Peramivir, vanco and aztreonam for
   bacterial overgrowth of pneumonia, was then restarted on
   Vanc/Cefepime/Cipro.
   - Will d/c ABx as above as we have no clear source that we are
   treating.
   - Follow up all cultures, including catheter tip and mini-BAL
   # DM2: Was on insulin gtt until recently, but now switched to Glargine
   40U qhs and SSI. Has increasing SSI needs; now on tubefeeds
   - Glargine has been recently increased to 45 qhs
   - Watch BS's through the day and increase accordingly
   # Tachycardia: Previously appeared to have multifocal atrial
   tachycardia. Patient started previously on Lopressor; then held for
   tenuous clinical status.
   - monitor on telemetry
   # Anemia: Hematocrits stable for several days now after trending down
   on admission.  Will continue to monitor daily.
   -transfuse if below 21
   #PEG placement: Currently getting Novasource renal

   - F/u PT consult

    #Renal failure: Urine output and creatinine have improved.  Had
   component of ATN with muddy casts in urine.  Has really improved with
   treatment and improvement of ARDS.
   - Renal team has signed off
   - Cr within baseline
   # Eye redness and discharge: Per nursing, patient had contact in his
   right eye which was only removed the other day as there was no record
   that patient wore contacts. Unable to find contact in left eye.  Seen
   by ophthalmology who mentioned that contact was intentionally there.
   Also suggested some changes to his eye-drops and outpatient follow-up.
    Patient already has outpatient appointment set up.
   - Prednisolone and tobramycin drops to R eye as prescribed.
   - Artificial tears ointment to both eyes
   # Rash: Rash improved after zosyn d/c
d.  No signs of DRESS.  Did have
   some follicles which are improving.
   - Chlorhexadine wash on arms and legs to help prevent infection of
   follicles
   # Hypothyroidism: Per most recent d/c summary, Synthroid at 50mcg daily
   or 25 IV.  Continued here.
   #GERD: PPI

   Access: 1 peripherals, A-line. Placed order for PICC to be placed
   tomorrow, for antibiotic delivery.

   Communication: Father and mother who are in to see him daily.
   Disposition: Pending improved respiratory status.
